segments.text: She looked around and was horrified.
From the first step she took on the path, she noticed the garden was desperate for water.
The flower stems were drooping, their tips tinged with brown and the grass was starting to turn yellow.
She took the key from its hiding place, opened the door and pushed it inward, stepping on newspapers piled underneath from recent days.
Dimness greeted her and a stale smell rose to her nose.
As usual, she removed her shoes at the entrance and briskly approached the glass doors leading to the large barden balcony, opening them wide door by door.
Then, she opened the windows and the red wooden shutters, securing them from outside with the metal fastener that looked like a little statue, one that everyone called Menchal.
A gentle breeze swept in and light flooded the dining room and the paintings on its walls.
She went outside and turned on the sprinklers.
It wasn't that she was surprised.
Lately, this is what she found almost every time she came home.
Still, each time, her heart ached a little.
Where had he gone?
Where was he wandering?
She tried to understand his heart and she couldn't quite manage.
The last time she saw Yosef was a little over two weeks ago.
Everyone called him Yosef with the emphasis on the second syllable.
Never Yosef with the emphasis on the first.
This added an aura of importance.
But mainly emphasized the pure Hebrew he spoke since the days of the Hebrew Gymnasium in Lithuania.
only when the oil drillers from Texas lived with them.
Those who set up the first oil drilling in Halets, only then, for almost two years, they called him Joe.
And Lucia became Lucy.
She called him Daddy.
Two weeks earlier, she unexpectedly came home in the middle of the week, after a school day was canceled, and she happened to have a ride from Tel Aviv.
For several months she had been studying in the 8th grade at an external school, after deciding to skip the 7th grade and stay by Lucy's side, who was already bedridden.
She shared a room with the daughter of one of Lucy's friends in a house in the suburbs of Ramat Gan, coming home mainly on weekends.
Almost always when a class was cancelled or her time was freed unexpectedly, she'd take Bus Line 5 from Bait Ha Hayal and get off at Had Passage.
There, near the famous milk bar, right across, was a small store for records and sheet music.
Browsing among the sheet music for all her favorite tunes and songs gave her special pleasure.
She wasn't very good at reading music, for she played by ear, but below the musical notations were the lyrics, and from that she would play.
At least she knew which note and scale to start with.
The rest simply flowed to her fingers.
Some of the booklets piled up on the floor in a corner of the store, and you could sense that no hand had touched them in a long time.
Dust accumulated on them, and a slight smell of mildew surrounded them.
Sometimes when she couldn't stand the mess of the dusty pile in the corner, she'd take a cloth, clean the booklets, sort them by theme, and then return each group to the correct shelf.
Rony, the store owner, noticed this only afterwards and would laugh.
You're ruining my store.
People won't recognize it without the dust.
Just before she stepped into the store, she heard a voice calling from behind her.
Annabelle Lee from A Kingdom By The Sea.
She turned her head and saw Avi, Danny's brother grinning at her mischievously.
She returned a playful smile and said, only Danny is allowed to call me that.
It's his invention.
Oh well.
But I'm also a resident of The Kingdom By The Sea, so I'm allowed to.
Do you want to ride home?
I just need to finish my milkshake and head back.
Sure," she replied without hesitation, a joyous smile on her lips.
The thought of a few good hours at home without the hassle of buses delighted her.
Rony, the store owner, recognized her at the door and came out to greet her.
Hey, kid, you won't believe it.
I found Misty for you and saved it aside.
How great.
Thanks, Rony.
I don't have any money, so I'll take it when I come next week.
Nonsense, he said.
Take it and pay when you come.
She didn't argue, knowing he meant what he said.
Over the past year, they had become friends from being strangers.
Misty was her song.
She couldn't remember what captivated her first, the wonderful melody that flowed and floated on the keys like a classical piece or the equally amazing lyrics.
Look at me, I'm as helpless as a kitten up a tree, and I feel like I'm clinging to a cloud.
I can't understand, I get misty just holding your hand.
Look at me, helpless as a kitten in a treetop, feeling like I'm clinging to a cloud, not understanding, completely overwhelmed just by holding your hand.
What made her stop in her tracks by the piano in her pink house?
When she heard Paulette, the singer, sing it while accompanying herself on the piano.
What made a girl, not even fifteen, fall completely in love with a song long before she knew anything real about love?
Maybe it was only the deep understanding that this was what she hoped to feel when it happened.
She took the booklet from Rani, waved goodbye and joined Avi.
They walked together to his car.
So what's the deal with Annabelle Lee?
He asked her as they began to drive.
It's a lovely poem by an English poet named Edgar Allen Poe about a princess named Annabelle Lee from a kingdom by the sea.
Danny heard me recite it once and decided in his wild imagination that I'm Annabelle Lee and Ashkelon is the kingdom by the sea.
Since then he calls me that.
It's a secret between friends, she said with a smile.
You know, he says you're like the little sister he doesn't have.
What can we do?
We're four boys just like in the Passover Haggadah.
They drove in silence for a while, then he turned to her with a smile.
Maybe recite the poem for me, he asked.
Leora smiled back, leaned her head on the car seat, closed her eyes and began to recite quietly and expressively.
It was many and many a year ago, in a kingdom by the sea, that a maiden there lived, whom you may know by the name of Annabelle Lee.
And this maiden she lived with no other thought than to love and be loved by me.
An hour later, the car stopped right at her doorstep and she got out slowly, waving him goodbye and calling out, thanks.
She pushed the heavy wooden door and stepped inside.
Joseph was seated at one of the tables with Cohen.
He jumped up to greet her and hugged her tightly.
How wonderful!
What a surprise!
She kissed him, leaned towards Cohen and placed a hand on his shoulder.
Daddy, we need to air out here and turn on the sprinklers.
Did you call Fortuna to cook and clean a bit?
Yosef burst into laughter.
The girl is like her mother, immediately organizing the house.
but then his face clouded a little.
Fortuna isn't coming anymore.
She's already tired.
And honestly, I'm trying to save wherever I can.
For so many years, Fortuna was an integral part of this house.
A short stout woman with round features, small dark eyes and hair pulled back in a bun.
There wasn't a hint of charm in those features.
Once she saw her combing her hair before going home and couldn't believe how long it was black with streaks of silver woven in.
Her beauty was in her hair.
She was always dressed in a simple, long dress that covered everything.
Her hands were swollen and red from years of hard work and cleaning since childhood.
But despite the appearance, they were very soft to the touch.
Lucy would provide her with tubes of glycerin cream, and at the end of each working day, she would rub her hands with cream, rubbing her palms together again and again as if in some ritual.
More than ten years passed since she first came to them looking for work.
Lucy needed help and welcomed her gladly.

Fortuna didn't know a word of Hebrew, only Moroccan Arabic and French, and their communication involved a lot of mime and hand gestures, which often sparked bursts of laughter in those who saw them talking.
They understood each other without words.

But during one of her visits, the French ambassador brought Lucy A. Gift of a blue book for learning French, and within a few months, Lucy was already speaking fluid French with Fortuna, even adopting an accent for it.
A great fondness existed between these two very different women.
One a lady, very beautiful, with her gray eyes, arched eyebrows, and silver hair with that white strand dyed into it on that terrible night by the Yarkon River.
She always smelled wonderful, had noble manners, and looked amazing even after hours of kitchen work at the hotel.

She knew how to speak in seven languages with everyone, with counts as with hardworking laborers, ministers and prime ministers as with truck drivers and guards, and with Fortuna, of course, and the other, a hardworking woman, a survivor, full bodied, slightly neglected, spending day after day mainly in labor until gradually she made this house her own.
She had no family, no husband, no children.
She received a two-room apartment from the agency and there she mainly stayed.
Every morning at 6.30, Fortuna would be in the kitchen starting to organize the day.
Chopping salad, polishing the counter, arranging in small dishes the herring, butter and jam for breakfast.
Waiting for Lucy to come and meticulously set the tables, spreading white cloths and placing napkins under every fork.
shining the glasses with a clean kitchen towel and placing a small vase of flowers on each table.
That's how it was for years.
They had their own language and humor, and a mere glance between them conveyed what one meant to the other.
There was also respect between them.

Lucy honored her as a person, respected her simplicity, felt compassion for her loneliness, recognized when she felt a little unwell, and immediately had her sit, checked what was happening, and didn't allow her to get up until she was sure she'd recovered.
At the end of each day, she would provide her with cooked food, bread, eggs, and vegetables.
Two women so different, whose eyes lit up anew each morning when they saw each other.
Then Lucy died, and Fortuna mourned for her as she knew from the village she came from, beyond the Atlas Mountains, deeply from a broken heart, loudly.
For a moment, her eyes shifted from Yosef to Cohen.
Some people's appearance will always reflect who they are, so it was with him.
Some people called him Cohen the Fat because of his large belly, but few knew his first name.

Whenever he finished eating, he would take his glasses, a pack of cigarettes, and the newspaper, and move to sit in the armchair Lucy and Joseph loved, between the reception counter and the entrance to the dining room.
It was like a small lobby, more like a large niche, with the piano in one corner, a blue painting hanging above it,
A man and a woman, somewhat exposed but not completely, sipping from goblets they held above their heads while almost floating over a row of houses by the sea.
It was an exceptional picture, blending the moon's white glow with a mysterious blue.
She was sure Yosef was drunk when he painted it, but there was no doubt the result was wonderful.
In the second corner stood a high-backed armchair, fully upholstered, with an ottoman decided, holding all the most notable newspapers and magazines from Newsweek and Time to this world.

At the base of the armchair, almost up to the piano, lay an old Persian rug Lucy had bought from the flea market, and above it hung an oil painting of the door beside it, open wide, with a view of the Chinaberry tree beyond, just like in reality, in dark green colors with palette knife strokes, even the edge of the rug peeks in it, every once in a while.
That armchair would catch fire, and the upholstery would be replaced.
They both were heavy smokers.
Lucy with her dubeck and Yosef with his Nelson without a filter.
That armchair served them both as a refuge for a short nap in the afternoon.
Each time one of them would fall into a light sleep, the cigarette in their mouth falling on the armchair and slowly scorching and burning it.
And each time one of them would jump as if snarled by a snake, curse colorfully and beat the small fire out with the newspaper on their lap and so for years that old armchair.
stood there changing and renewing itself at least two or three times a year.
Rosa from the market would bring Lucy fabrics to choose from and Lucy would rummage through them until she found one she liked.
Cutting, fitting, spreading the new fabric over the old one and fastening it with large tacks from behind.

and lo and behold there's a new armchair always floral in warm pastel colors it was a hugging armchair wide enough very soft and you could almost hide in it during quiet and solitary hours she'd curl up inside crossing her legs underneath and sinking into reading a book sometimes she'd indulge in a light nap while nestled in it a good nap that sneaks upon you unnoticed leaving you calm and good-hearted upon waking
And now the armchair bowed under Cohen's bulk.
The evening newspaper spread over his belly, a cigarette at the end of his mouth engrossed in reading.
For years he had been coming there almost daily, sitting and eating lunch, sometimes returning in the evening for a poker game or a drink at the bar.
She knew he missed Lucy dearly.
It seemed as if since she passed, he had been searching for her every time he came.
People knew very little about Cohen.
He wasn't a big talker and he was a mystery to everyone.
Outwardly, he was always the polish broker with wealth and reach.
But Lucy knew everything.
And she, what did she know about Cohen?
Only once, a long time ago.
Did she hear Lucy telling that his son, who was a regular guest with them on holidays or vacations, and had become a close friend over the years, wasn't his biological son?
He was his wife's child from a previous marriage, and after a few years she passed away too, leaving him to care for the boy as a single parent.

He was a lonely man whose appearance spoke of wealth and fortitude, and over the years, he and his son had almost become family to her, providing a sort of uncle figure, forming part of her childhood landscape.
A man with a large belly and skinny legs.
A shiny bald head accentuated his above-the-ears hairline, and he was always dressed tip-top, as Lucy would say.
His shoes always looked new and shiny, and he smelled of brute aftershave.
But beneath all that tip-top, his eyes gave him away.
He had kind eyes, and he called her Maydale.
Like before, she found the note on the entrance door.
We'll return on Monday, Yosef.

Once she finished turning on the sprinklers with all the glass doors wide open, she proceeded to the shelf by the kitchen entrance, removed her shirt and remained in her undershirt, changing into the shorts folded aside, braiding her hair into a long braid.
She was already barefoot as usual after leaving her shoes at the entrance.
She stepped out again, opened the water tap.
and washed the entire porch of accumulated dust and sand with a strong stream from the hose.
Then she went inside, took the squeegee, and began to mop the whole dining room energetically from end to end.
reaching every corner, under the armchair, around the piano, shifting the bar stools and returning them after mopping underneath, then moving on to the kitchen.
After washing everything, she opened the back door and poured all the water from the bucket along the path.
She spread a dry rag at the entrance, wiped her bare feet, and stepped back in.
She felt hunger creeping in her belly.
I've got to cook something, she thought to herself.
I'll clean the rooms later.
She opened the drawer at the reception desk, took the little money that was there from the cash box and put it in her pocket.
Then she headed to the edge of the garden where Jumbo the horse stood, munching on hay to his delight.
She untied the rope from the tree to which he was tethered, hugged his neck and padded his face, whispering to him, Bonjour mon amour.
With a light jump, she mounted his back, hugged his neck, clicked her tongue, and directed him toward the garden gate.
They walked slowly to Albert's grocery store.
You came with your limo?
Albert asked.
How are you, child?
Good to see you.
She bought vegetables and fresh bread at the store.
It's aroma.
Only intensifying her hunger, so she broke the kiss and popped it into her mouth in the meantime.
Then she moved from Albert to Moses, the butcher next door, and received a bundle of greetings from him too.
He sliced chicken thighs for her, pounded chicken breast for schnitzels, and packed it all in a big bag accompanying her outside.
Now Albert joined with the bag she had left with him, and both stood waiting for her to mount the horse, each passing their package to her, smiling broadly and waving goodbye.
They stood watching her until she vanished with the horse in the distance.
Look at them, Albert remarked to Moses the butcher, as if they walked out of a picture.
Once she heard Lucy say that any dish starting with frying onions cannot fail and the aroma it emits will always smell like home.
She was right, of course.
Now Leora chopped the onion, whitening the tears it brought out.
Only onion chopping made tears roll down her cheeks.
Since Lucy had passed, her tears had lost direction and didn't know how to roll anymore.
If they rose to her eyes for any reason, they stopped at the edge, refusing to continue and roll down the cheeks.
She added a little oil to the pot, and while the onion fried, she seasoned the chicken pieces, adding them one by one to brown.
She added garlic, tomato paste, and a little water, brought it to a boil, lowered it to a simmer, and covered it.
Then she peeled the potatoes, diced them, and added them to the dish, leaving it to cook slowly.
Now with the sprinklers humming in the garden, the house clean and washed from end to end, and a pot of food cooking on a low flame.
She could take a deep breath and relax.
She filled her favorite beer glass with cold water and drank it eagerly, leaning on the bar, using her other hand to wipe sweat from her forehead.
Suddenly, she felt someone watching her.
She turned her head, a broad smile spreading across her face.
Danny approached the entrance door, cupping his hands around his mouth and shouting, Annabelle Lee.
But the door remained closed.
No one answered.
The note on the door, still announced, will return on Monday, Yosef.
He pondered Yosef's behavior the last time they met.
You don't understand, she told him forgivingly.
Why be mad at him?
He's like a child running around searching for sweets.
Danny was about to turn back when he heard a nae from the garden's edge.
He turned his gaze and saw the stableman's horse from the French resort, munching on hay left before him.
All the garden furniture was upturned, the porch wet and washed, the sprinklers were on at the other side of the garden.
The large glass doors leading from the porch to the dining room were open wide, revealing chairs turned over tables.
The floor was shiny and damp from mopping, and a pleasant stew aroma wafted in the air.
He began to walk in, momentarily forgetting he mustn't step on the wet.
Out of the corner of his eye he saw her leaning on the bar.
A girl in shorts, a tank top, a braid on one shoulder, barefoot drinking water thirstily from a large beer mug, hand and dabbing sweat from her forehead.
As if she felt his gaze, she suddenly turned, saw him, smiled broadly, and shouted, Mr. Edgar Allen Poe, don't you dare step on my wet floor.
She pulled a drink bottle from the fridge, came out to him on the porch, and sat with him.
When did you arrive, since everything is already clean and tidy?
two hours ago.
I've already been to the grocery and set up some cooking.
I'm starving.
If you wait a bit, we can eat together.
I must finish cleaning the rooms and changing towels and sheets before everyone returns.
The note says when he'll be back, but not since when he's been gone.
Who knows how many days they were abandoned.
Even Fortuna isn't coming anymore.
She's tired.
Maybe a bit disheartened to relax in the lounger and take a nap.
You look done in by the time you wake up, everything will be finished.
She turned and walked away, crossing the dining room to the area of the rooms.
Loaded with a pile of sheets and towels, returning to fetch the bucket with cleaning supplies in the mop, she disappeared again.
Slowly his eyes closed.
He sank into a deep sleep, letting fatigue take over.
When he opened them, it was already getting dark.
He noticed he was covered with a light blanket.
Yellow light flooded the dining room and filled Yosef's paintings.
He rose slowly, noticing the set table.
Two people were seated there.
One was a veterinarian who had been living there off and on for the last two or three years.
He didn't recognize the other one.
As he moved forward, Leora emerged from the kitchen with heaping plates, smiling at him.
Good morning.
I didn't have the heart to wake you.
I called your mother so she wouldn't worry and told her you were resting exhausted in my garden.
Danny went to wash his face and joined the table, marveling once more at how she managed to put together a meal in five minutes from two and a half ingredients.
probably learned from years watching her mom, who produced real delicacies from this hotel kitchen.
The doctor turned to him and asked how the flight course was going and how much longer it would last.
And in the same breath introduced him to the other guy at the table.
Meet Yoski, he's the truck driver parked at the entrance.
He suddenly remembered, this was the guy who nearly a year ago walked into the lobby calling loudly, Lucinka, where are you?
Pale and agitated, Leora had seated him, explaining that Lucenca had passed away two months prior, and the large man burst into tears.
What a woman!
What a lady!
Don't meet women like that anymore.
I used to tell her all my problems.
She always gave good advice, put me in my place.
She patched things up at home with my wife.
Since then, he had occasionally stayed there.
The doctor went behind the bar, fetched a bottle of wine, uncorked it, and poured everyone a glass.
What shall we toast to?
he asked, and Danny with a sincere expression answered to Annabelle Lee.
The wine flowed down his throat and a comfortable feeling spread through him.
There was something very familial about this strange group gathered around the table.
This is what she does.
She makes a home, silently taking charge, organizing things with responsibility, carrying out a mission her mother left her without making a fuss or complaining about her absent father.
This house is supposed to serve as a home, even for the people who come to it.
That's how mom taught her.
And she tries to secure that feeling.
Maybe she simply clings to this in as an anchor, navigating the days where the outcome is unpredictable.
Suddenly the phone rang.
She got up to answer.
Danny heard her replying in English mingled with French to Paulette, who was just checking if she had arrived and if she might come to play a bit together.
Leora returned to the table, declaring, well, the quiet is over.
It's going to be lively here soon.
The singer is on her way.
She cleared the table and everyone helped her move the dishes to the sink.
She started washing them and the doctor stood drying.
Teen work, he thought to himself.
Habits became second nature, a rather peculiar atmosphere.
People pay for lodging and a meal, clear the table, and stand drying the dishes afterward.
One could feel the warmth in the air they felt towards this girl, and she towards them.
Sorry, I'm missing the concert, Danny said.
I have to go.
He gave her a hug and left.
A little earlier, when the doctor arrived with his tiny sports car, he saw her near the hotel riding a horse without a saddle, clutching its mane, and they ambled slowly.
She'd surely popped by to fetch a few groceries from the nearby store.
Everyone has their vehicle.
He smiled to himself.
For two years, Robert, the resort's stableman, had been bringing this charming horse to their courtyard at the start of winter to shield it from sea winds and cold.
It was his personal horse, and he named it Jumbo, like the French sausage.
He opened the room door, inhaling the scent of cleanliness.
He instantly noticed the fresh towels and sheets, understanding she had already dealt with the rooms.
How delightful!
It had been several days since anyone had cleaned there.
He tried to recall how he first arrived at the pink inn.
He was sent to stay there to attend to the horses and cows of the local farmers.
Within a few days, he realized he was home.
The phone calls summoning him for urgent cases reached the hotel reception, and Lucy would call out.
Danny Boy, come quick, the cow needs you.
Her deep voice laughing.
After an episode of severe back pains left him unable to move, finding himself sprawled on the dining room floor, she treated him like a baby.
Called a doctor, applied ointments, and slowly within a few days, he was back on his feet.
Since then, he'd become her protégé.
She was a friend, a mother, and a sister.
This daughter of theirs entered his heart as part of the warm relationship formed.
Sometimes when he left for work at the right time, he'd give her a lift to school and flaunt his sports car to all her friends.
There were many deep conversations between them.
He shared insights about life in the big world, particularly about America, where he studied veterinary science.
She pestered him with countless questions, eager to learn.
He was amazed when she was reading the human comedy by Soroyan in English, sitting at the piano, pouring her heart into it with Frank Sinatra, Eve Montand, and others recognized only by grown-ups.
all by ear, without sheet music.
He'd tell Lucy the girl had an exotic blend of wild child with royalty manners.
She's provincial with a window, he'd describe.
He sensed something broken her after Lucy's passing.
He could feel the sadness in her eyes even when she smiled, trying to breeze through life, not letting anyone sense sorrow for her, displaying quiet confidence in everything she did.
He was sure it was just a facade.
Deep in his heart, he knew she felt a profound sadness and a great loneliness.
He remembered that before Lucy passed, she made a brave decision not to start the seventh grade, but to stay by her mother's side.
I can always catch up with studies.
Mom will be here in two months.
She firmly stated to Yosef.
He saw her as a fully grown person and agreed.
She was only fifteen and a half, and the doctor thought to himself he should remember she was still a child.
To an outside observer, it's sometimes seemed they had switched roles.
She became the responsible adult, whereas he would occasionally wander to the big city as he pleased, without stopping to consider the consequences this might have on her.
And nevertheless, no doubt, that father of hers loved her with all his heartstrings.
She was now studying externally in Tel Aviv, sharing a room with the daughter of her parents' friends for several nights a week, coming home only on weekends or holidays.
Often, she'd find Yosef's note on the door, notifying he'd be away for several days.
Sometimes she wouldn't see him for nearly two weeks.
In a flash, she'd accomplish all the required tasks, then, until the floor dried, sit at the piano and pour all her frustrations there.
By the melodies she played, one could sense her mood.
Sometimes she pounded the keys fiercely.
Other times, she caressed them gently with her fingers.
Or, you might find her curled into the armchair in the corner, with a book in hand.
Always reading.
Everything.
Devouring books.
Historical novels.
Ayn Rand.
Poetry volumes in Hebrew or English.
He was in absolute shock hearing her first time recite Annabelle Lee by Edgar Allan Poe in flawless English, from beginning to end with intonation and clear enjoyment of the content.
She was barely 14.
That's when he understood why Danny the Younger called her Annabelle Lee.
To him, she was like in the poem, a sort of princess in a kingdom by the sea.
He learned from Lucy that English had stayed with her since the time when ten Texas oil drillers resided at the Pink Inn for about two years, setting up the first oil drilling in Helettes.
Overnight, the place turned into an American stronghold and English became the dominant language.
She was almost seven when they left, but the language was embedded in her memory.
Slowly, she was becoming a lady, clean from all pretenses of grooming, a bit of a tomboy, no pretense, just the blue of her eyes.
With that dreamy look and long hair, sometimes loose, sometimes braided behind her, still strolling barefoot almost until winter came.
no longer a child, not yet a woman, with the depth of a mature person who's already been through some things in life, strangely mingled with youthful innocence, a princess of her own kingdom.
